Situation1: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story: I sat at the long conference table, my stomach already tight with nerves. This was the final team meeting before we locked in the project decisions, and everyone’s eyes were on me to contribute. Plates of food were passed around—catered sandwiches, salads, and pastries, none of them marked with the kosher certification I needed. I could feel my manager’s expectation: be present, be part of the team, share a meal, and show I’m invested. But as a Jew, I couldn’t just eat what was offered. I glanced at my colleagues, laughing and chatting, plates full, and felt the weight of standing apart. Bringing my own food would draw attention, maybe even questions I wasn’t ready to answer. Skipping the meal might seem rude or distant, but eating would mean compromising my values. The pressure built inside me, torn between being the reliable teammate everyone expected and staying true to my faith. I stared at the untouched food in front of me, heart pounding, caught between two worlds, unsure which expectation I could bear to disappoint.
